title: 113_hr5652
content: The Act may be cited as the "Fiscal Responsibility Using Government Accountability Laws Act of 2014" or the "FRUGAL Act." It includes provisions for the enforcement of offshore tax policies. The "FRUGAL Act" requires the Treasury Inspector General for Tax Administration to analyze taxpayer compliance in reporting foreign accounts and submit a report to Congress within a year of the Act's enactment. The "FRUGAL Act" mandates the Treasury Inspector General for Tax Administration to analyze offshore tax compliance and report to Congress. The report must detail taxpayer circumvention of voluntary compliance initiatives, lost revenue, and recommendations to close offshore tax loopholes. Additionally, the Commissioner of Internal Revenue is required to enhance educational outreach on taxpayer offshore tax obligations. The "FRUGAL Act" requires the Commissioner of Internal Revenue to improve targeting taxpayers with offshore accounts and use data from offshore programs to identify taxpayers with unreported foreign accounts. Additionally, a report must be submitted to Congress within 1 year detailing these efforts. The report to Congress will outline how the IRS plans to close offshore tax loopholes and provide recommendations for increasing revenue collection from offshore sources. SEC. 3. REVERSE AUCTIONS IN GOVERNMENT CONTRACTING. The Federal Acquisition Regulation will be revised to clarify the use of reverse auctions by Federal agencies, including guidelines for efficient use and ensuring high quality standards and small business participation. Reverse auction is defined as a real-time electronic auction where offerors compete by submitting bids for a contract or order. Revised bids are submitted throughout the auction, with the lowest bid winning the award. SEC. 4. COIN INVENTORY MANAGEMENT PLAN AND REPORT. The Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System must develop a plan to reduce spending on coin inventory management within 180 days of the enactment of this Act. The plan should assess factors increasing costs, monitor direct and indirect costs, set goals and metrics, and track forecasting models. A report with a timeline for plan implementation must be submitted to Congress. The plan must include a timeline for implementing objectives, accuracy of monthly coin order forecasts, and cost-effective coin management practices across Federal Reserve banks.
